title: Abortion Rights
content: The Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971 allows abortion under specific conditions, emphasizing women's autonomy. Amendments in 2021 extended permissible gestation limits for certain categories of women. While the law promotes reproductive rights, access and awareness remain uneven across the country.
act: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971 (Amended 2021)

title: Uniform Civil Code
content: The Uniform Civil Code (UCC), proposed under Article 44 of the Constitution, advocates for a common set of laws governing personal matters like marriage, divorce, and inheritance for all citizens regardless of religion. Proponents argue it promotes equality and secularism; critics raise concerns over cultural homogenization.
act: Article 44, Constitution of India

title: Caste-Based Reservation
content: Caste-based reservation in India provides affirmative action for historically disadvantaged groups such as Scheduled Castes (SC), Scheduled Tribes (ST), and Other Backward Classes (OBC). Rooted in the Constitution, it aims to promote equal opportunity but remains a contentious issue in debates around meritocracy and social equity.
act: Articles 15 & 16, Constitution of India

title: Same-Sex Marriage
content: While the Supreme Court decriminalized homosexuality in 2018, same-sex marriage remains legally unrecognized. Current petitions before the courts challenge the constitutionality of denying marriage equality to LGBTQ+ individuals under Articles 14, 15, and 21.
act: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India (2018); Articles 14, 15, 21

title: Marital Rape Laws
content: Indian Penal Code Section 375 excludes marital rape from the definition of rape, stating that intercourse by a man with his wife (not under 18) is not rape. Legal and feminist activists argue this exception violates women’s rights to bodily autonomy and dignity.
act: Section 375, Indian Penal Code; Article 21, Constitution of India

title: Death Penalty
content: The death penalty remains a legal form of punishment in India for the 'rarest of rare' crimes, as upheld in the Bachan Singh case. Critics argue it violates human rights and is prone to judicial errors, while supporters claim it deters heinous crimes.
act: Indian Penal Code; Bachan Singh v. State of Punjab (1980)

title: Freedom of Speech
content: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2), including public order and national security. The balance between expression and regulation remains a constant debate.
act: Article 19(1)(a) and 19(2), Constitution of India

title: Sedition Laws
content: Section 124A of the IPC defines sedition and punishes acts that incite hatred or disaffection against the government. Critics argue that sedition laws are colonial remnants often used to suppress dissent. The Supreme Court is reviewing its constitutional validity.
act: Section 124A, Indian Penal Code

title: Right to Privacy
content: Declared a fundamental right under Article 21 by the Supreme Court in the Puttaswamy judgment, the right to privacy protects individuals against arbitrary state intrusion. It forms the foundation for data protection, bodily autonomy, and digital rights.
act: Justice K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India (2017); Article 21

title: Religious Freedom
content: Articles 25 to 28 guarantee the right to profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order and morality. These rights are central to India’s secular identity but face friction when religious customs conflict with other constitutional principles.
act: Articles 25–28, Constitution of India

title: Anti-Conversion Laws
content: Anti-conversion laws in India aim to regulate religious conversions and prohibit conversions by force, fraud, or inducement. These laws have been enacted in several states and have sparked debate over religious freedom and the misuse of the law to target minorities.
act: Various State Acts; Article 25 of the Constitution

title: Mob Lynching
content: Mob lynching refers to extrajudicial killings carried out by a group, often under the pretext of cow protection or religious/caste intolerance. The Supreme Court has urged states to enact specific laws, yet a central anti-lynching law is still pending.
act: Tehseen S. Poonawalla v. Union of India (2018); IPC Sections 302, 34

title: Triple Talaq
content: Triple Talaq, or instant divorce in Islam, was declared unconstitutional in the Shayara Bano case. It was subsequently criminalized through legislation in 2019, aiming to protect Muslim women's rights and promote gender justice.
act: Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019

title: Internet Shutdowns
content: India leads globally in internet shutdowns, often imposed for law and order concerns. The Supreme Court, in the Anuradha Bhasin case, ruled that access to the internet is part of freedom of expression under Article 19(1)(a).
act: Anuradha Bhasin v. Union of India (2020); Article 19(1)(a)

title: Surveillance vs Privacy
content: The conflict between state surveillance and individual privacy has intensified in the digital age. Concerns over Pegasus spyware and lack of comprehensive data protection laws highlight the need for balancing national security and civil liberties.
act: Puttaswamy Judgment (2017); IT Act, 2000

title: Right to Protest
content: The right to peaceful protest is protected under Article 19. However, recent crackdowns and misuse of laws like UAPA have raised concerns about shrinking democratic space in India.
act: Article 19(1)(b); Shaheen Bagh Case (Amit Sahni v. Commissioner of Police)

title: Live-in Relationships
content: Live-in relationships, while not formally recognized in personal laws, have been granted legal protection by courts in matters of maintenance and domestic violence, emphasizing adult autonomy and choice.
act: Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005; Supreme Court Judgments

title: Minimum Age of Consent
content: In India, the legal age of consent is 18. However, this clashes with social realities and romantic relationships among adolescents, leading to criminalization under POCSO even in consensual cases.
act: POCSO Act, 2012

title: Media Trials
content: Media trials can influence public opinion and judicial outcomes, undermining the presumption of innocence. Courts have criticized such coverage but lack specific legal regulation of pre-trial media behavior.
act: Contempt of Courts Act, 1971; Article 21

title: Whistleblower Protection
content: The Whistle Blowers Protection Act was passed in 2014 to protect individuals exposing corruption. However, delays in implementation and proposed amendments dilute its effectiveness and discourage reporting.
act: Whistle Blowers Protection Act, 2014

title: Freedom of the Press
content: Though not explicitly mentioned in the Constitution, freedom of the press is derived from Article 19(1)(a). Increasing censorship, sedition charges, and media ownership concentration threaten press freedom.
act: Article 19(1)(a); Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras (1950)

title: LGBTQ+ Rights
content: Section 377 was decriminalized in 2018, marking a landmark victory for LGBTQ+ rights. However, full equality in areas like marriage, adoption, and anti-discrimination laws remains pending.
act: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India (2018); Section 377 IPC

title: Child Labor Laws
content: India prohibits the employment of children below 14 in hazardous occupations. Amendments in 2016 allow family enterprises and entertainment work, sparking criticism over exploitation loopholes.
act: Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 (amended 2016)

title: Juvenile Justice
content: Juvenile Justice laws aim to reform rather than punish. After the 2012 Delhi gang rape, amendments allowed 16-18 year olds to be tried as adults in heinous crimes under judicial discretion.
act: Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015

title: AFSPA and Military Powers
content: The Armed Forces Special Powers Act grants immunity to military personnel in 'disturbed areas'. It has been criticized for human rights violations and lack of accountability, especially in the Northeast and Kashmir.
act: AFSPA, 1958

title: Gun Control
content: India has some of the strictest gun laws globally, requiring licenses and extensive checks. Recent debates focus on regulating illegal firearms and preventing misuse in communal or political violence.
act: Arms Act, 1959

title: Euthanasia Debate
content: Passive euthanasia has been legalized in India through advance directives. The ethical and legal debates around active euthanasia and right to die continue to evolve.
act: Common Cause v. Union of India (2018); Article 21

title: Data Protection Laws
content: India's Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023, aims to safeguard individual data. Critics argue it lacks strong enforcement mechanisms and grants excessive government exemptions.
act: Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

title: Cryptocurrency Regulation
content: India lacks specific crypto laws, though trading is not banned. The government has introduced a 30% tax on crypto gains and is working on a regulatory framework amid concerns over scams and investor protection.
act: Finance Act, 2022 (crypto tax); Draft Banning of Cryptocurrency Bill (not passed)

title: Environmental Justice
content: Environmental justice in India involves protecting vulnerable communities from ecological harm. While the judiciary has played an active role through directives and PILs, gaps remain in implementation, regulatory enforcement, and public accountability.
act: Environment (Protection) Act, 1986; National Green Tribunal Act, 2010

title: Climate Change Laws
content: India’s legal response to climate change includes a mix of environmental regulations, international commitments like the Paris Agreement, and domestic initiatives such as the National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC). However, the absence of a consolidated climate law raises concerns about enforceability, coordination, and long-term accountability in addressing emissions, resilience, and climate justice.
act: Environment (Protection) Act, 1986; National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC); Paris Agreement (ratified)

title: Secularism vs Majority
content: India’s constitutional secularism mandates equal respect for all religions. However, political majoritarianism often challenges this balance, leading to laws or policies perceived to favor the religious majority. Legal debates revolve around whether true secularism can survive when state neutrality appears compromised.
act: Articles 14, 15, 25–28, Constitution of India

title: Digital Censorship
content: Digital censorship involves the control or suppression of what can be accessed, published, or viewed on the internet. In India, legal tools like the IT Act, takedown notices, and content regulation guidelines often walk a thin line between protecting citizens and stifling dissent.
act: Information Technology Act, 2000; Intermediary Guidelines Rules, 2021

title: Gig Workers' Rights
content: Gig economy workers lack traditional employment benefits like job security, health insurance, and pensions. Recent steps like including gig workers in the Code on Social Security, 2020, aim to address this precariousness, though implementation challenges persist.
act: Code on Social Security, 2020

title: Women's Safety Laws
content: India has enacted multiple laws to ensure women’s safety, including laws against sexual harassment, domestic violence, and acid attacks. However, enforcement remains inconsistent, and victims often face social stigma and procedural hurdles in accessing justice.
act: Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013; IPC Sections 354, 376

title: Transgender Rights
content: The Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights) Act, 2019 provides legal recognition and anti-discrimination protections. Critics argue it fails to address real inclusion due to its flawed certification process and lack of reservation or healthcare mandates.
act: Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights) Act, 2019

title: Artificial Intelligence Laws
content: AI raises complex legal questions about accountability, ethics, bias, and job displacement. India currently lacks a dedicated AI law, though policy think tanks and NITI Aayog have released guidelines on responsible AI. The absence of binding regulation raises concerns.
act: Policy Guidelines (NITI Aayog); No codified law yet

title: Social Media Regulation
content: India’s regulation of social media platforms has tightened through the IT Rules, 2021, mandating grievance redressal, takedowns, and traceability of messages. Critics argue it enables censorship and surveillance while tech giants question compliance burdens.
act: Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules, 2021

title: Electoral Reforms
content: India's electoral reforms aim to enhance transparency, curb black money, and promote voter participation. Proposals include simultaneous elections, state funding of polls, and greater scrutiny of Electoral Bonds, which are criticized for opacity.
act: Representation of the People Act, 1951; Election Laws (Amendment) Act, 2021

title: One Nation, One Election
content: This proposal seeks synchronized elections across Parliament and State Assemblies to reduce costs and enhance governance. While seen as efficient, critics worry it undermines federalism and regional democratic expression.
act: Not codified yet; Policy proposal under consideration

title: Citizenship Laws
content: India’s citizenship framework came under intense scrutiny following the CAA 2019, which offers fast-track citizenship to non-Muslim migrants from select countries. Critics claim it violates secular principles and may marginalize Muslims when combined with NRC exercises.
act: Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019; Citizenship Act, 1955

title: National Security vs Civil Rights
content: Laws such as UAPA, NSA, and AFSPA are invoked to protect national security but have raised concerns for curtailing civil liberties. Courts have increasingly examined whether state actions maintain a fair balance with individual rights under Articles 14 and 21.
act: Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967; National Security Act, 1980

title: Caste Discrimination
content: Despite constitutional guarantees, caste discrimination persists in education, employment, and social interactions. Atrocities against Dalits remain prevalent, prompting calls for stricter enforcement of SC/ST laws and broader societal change.
act: Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989

title: Personal Data Ownership
content: The idea that individuals should own their personal data is gaining ground. While the DPDP Act, 2023 gives some control to users, many believe it falls short of true data sovereignty due to government exemptions and lack of portability rights.
act: Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

title: Media Regulation
content: Media regulation in India involves a mix of self-regulation and statutory control through the Cable TV Act, Press Council, and new IT Rules. While meant to ensure ethics and accuracy, these often clash with press freedom.
act: Cable Television Networks (Regulation) Act, 1995; IT Rules, 2021

title: Defamation Laws
content: Defamation in India can be both civil and criminal, raising debates on whether criminal defamation infringes on free speech. Section 499 of IPC has been upheld but faces increasing calls for decriminalization.
act: Section 499–500, Indian Penal Code; Article 19(1)(a)

title: Blasphemy and Free Speech
content: India does not have a formal blasphemy law, but laws like Sections 295A of IPC are used to prosecute speech that offends religious sentiments. Critics argue these suppress dissent and artistic expression.
act: Section 295A, Indian Penal Code

title: Interfaith Marriages
content: Interfaith marriages are legally allowed under the Special Marriage Act, 1954. However, procedural hurdles and rising opposition through ‘love jihad’ laws in some states have created a hostile environment.
act: Special Marriage Act, 1954

title: Education Reservation
content: Education reservations aim to correct historical injustices and promote inclusion. The 10% EWS quota introduced a new layer of complexity, raising constitutional and social equity debates.
act: Constitution (103rd Amendment) Act, 2019; Articles 15(4), 15(5), 15(6)

title: Fake News Laws
content: The rise of fake news has prompted legal action via IT laws and fact-check mechanisms. However, recent proposals to empower government fact-check units have sparked fears of overreach and censorship.
act: Information Technology Act, 2000; IT Rules, 2023 (Proposed)
